title: Kendrick Peak
text:
Kendrick Peak or Kendrick Mountain is one of the highest peaks in the <a href="San%20Francisco%20volcanic%20field">San Francisco volcanic field</a> north of the <a href="city">city</a> of <a href="Flagstaff%2C%20Arizona">Flagstaff</a> in the <a href="U.S.%20State">U.S. State</a> of <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a> and is located on the <a href="Coconino%20Plateau">Coconino Plateau</a> in <a href="Coconino%20County%2C%20Arizona">Coconino County</a>.
Kendrick Peak rises to a height of , which makes it the 11th or 12th tallest summit (depending on the source) in <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>. Kendrick Peak is a <a href="Lava%20dome">Lava dome</a> between 2.7 and 1.4 million years old consisting primarily of <a href="dacite">dacite</a> and <a href="rhyolite">rhyolite</a> flows that were partly buried by <a href="andesite">andesite</a> according to the <a href="USGS">USGS</a>.
Kendrick Peak is in the <a href="Kendrick%20Mountain%20Wilderness">Kendrick Mountain Wilderness</a> which is administered jointly by the <a href="Kaibab%20National%20Forest">Kaibab National Forest</a> and the <a href="Coconino%20National%20Forest">Coconino National Forest</a>. A <a href="fire%20lookout">fire lookout</a>, manned by the <a href="United%20States%20Forest%20Service">United States Forest Service</a> during the week and by volunteers on the weekends, has stood on top of Kendrick Peak since the early 1900s.
There are three maintained trails to the <a href="topographical%20summit">summit</a> of Kendrick Peak - Kendrick Mountain Trail, Pumpkin Trail and Bull Basin Trail.
Along the Kendrick Mountain Trail, near the summit of Kendrick Peak, there is a <a href="Colorado%20Pinyon">Colorado Pinyon</a> ("Pinus edulis") growing at an altitude of nearly . This is a rare high-elevation example of this species growing amongst <a href="Engelmann%20spruce">Engelmann spruce</a> ("Picea engelmannii") and <a href="limber%20pine">limber pine</a> ("Pinus flexilis").
In the year 2000, the Kendrick Wilderness and Kendrick Peak were involved in a large <a href="wildfire">wildfire</a>, the results of which are still quite evident to hikers or visitors to the peak. In an effort to return the forest to its "pre-fire" state, <a href="cattle">cattle</a> are sometimes grazed near the Kendrick Mountain Trail trailhead.
Geology.
Kendrick Peak is a <a href="dome%20volcano">dome volcano</a>, with some having multiple extrusion vents. Other Arizona examples of dome volcanoes are <a href="Mount%20Elden">Mount Elden</a>, Bill Williams Mountain, and Sitgreaves Mountain. See <a href="List%20of%20lava%20domes">List of lava domes</a> for more examples worldwide.
